data.text: Contents
Introduction

The Trust recognises that effective recruitment and selection practices are fundamental to its future success and that good selection can lead to better patient care, higher morale, and lower turnover of staff and lower rates of absenteeism.

This policy is designed to assist managers to get the best candidates for their vacancies and to fill vacancies within a reasonable timescale at a reasonable cost; all within best practice, following employment legislation, NHS standards and the Trusts Single Equality Scheme (SES). Medical Staffing appointments may be subject to additional guidelines and specialist advice should be sought from Human Resources, e.g. Consultant recruitment.
All appointments must be made in accordance with this policy. Any exceptions to the policy must be agreed with Human Resources Recruitment team in advance.
The Trust will always ensure all employees, temporary or permanent have been fully vetted and all the necessary mandatory NHS Employment Checks are completed prior to commencing work at the Trust.
When employing temporary or casual staff the principles of good practice outlined in this policy should be followed.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Enable managers to recruit and retain skilled people to enable the wider Trust to achieve its aims and values.
Ensure effective, consistent and fair practice by the provision of clear guidelines.
Ensure there is equality of opportunity for existing and prospective staff and to ensure there is no less favourable treatment of applicants.
Ensure recruiting managers are competent to fulfil their obligations within the policy and wherever possible have undergone relevant training.
Ensure that all staff have been appropriately vetted for the requirements of their role.

All appointments must be made in accordance with this policy and would therefore, be subject to approval, advertisement, short listing, interview and employment checks as below. Any exceptions to the policy must be agreed with Human Resources Recruitment team in advance.
All recruitment activity is to be in accordance with the Trusts Diversity and Equality of Opportunity Policy and the Trust Retirement Policy.
The Trust is part of the Disability Confident Employer scheme which guarantees an interview for all suitably qualified disabled applicants.
Definitions
Role and responsibilities within the Trust

It is the responsibility of each Head of Department/Division to ensure that this policy is carefully followed within their areas of responsibility; making sure their staff and in particular recruiting Managers aware of the obligation to familiarise themselves with and follow this policy.

Managers have a specific responsibility to ensure that any new employee has been properly recruited in accordance with this policy and in particular all pre-employment checks have been made such that they are satisfied that the employee is safe to practice. Managers must also fully utilise the available technology to assist with the process of recruitment for example fully using the capabilities of ‘TRAC' System and NHS Jobs.

The Human Resources Recruitment team will lead and be responsible for ensuring all technological and procedural aspects of the recruitment process as described in this policy are properly implemented and that managers are fully supported and enabled to undertake the recruitment process. See Appendix 3 for Process Maps detailing the recruitment process and the roles and responsibilities of individuals.
Recruiting the right resource
Workforce planning

Workforce planning activity undertaken by the Division or Departments and the HR Business partners, will show vacancies, gaps and current recruitment candidate pipelines for these vacancies. This is an opportunity to look at all of these factors and to discuss any potential intended changes in skill mix or any other significant organisational change and development. However it is also recognised that the dynamic climate of the NHS may create unforeseen opportunities.
Approvals procedure
All recruitment whether permanent or temporary roles require approval via the Trust Vacancy panel and or via the TRAC System job authorisation process. (See Appendix 6)
The Recruiting Manager completes the vacancy template on TRAC, in the context of current resourcing plans and any additional information with the aim of determining how best to fill the vacancy.

The manager then creates the vacancy request on TRAC and adds the appropriate supporting documents i.e. job description and personal specification; then adds authorisers for the vacancy, i.e. Divisional Manager, and alternate hiring managers and Finance Business partners.

Once completed the form is sent to the approvers to authorise the vacancy is sent to Management Accounts for financial approval. When approval is given TRAC will send it through to HR Recruitment Team who prepares vacancies to go through to the weekly Vacancy Control Panel (TVP). The Panel sits on a Friday morning. The TRAC request must be submitted by 17.00pm on Wednesday each week to be considered for the Friday panel.

If the vacancy is not a like for like replacement an establishment control form (ECF form) will be required with the approved business case in order to support the approval of the post at the vacancy control meeting refer to finance approvals policy.
Requests for variation to starting salaries are held in a separate panel, following the TVP process, each Friday the starting salary variation form is available in appendix 6.
All outcomes, whether approved or not, are communicated to Recruiting Managers the following working day, so Monday following the Friday review.
Advertising

The aim of advertising is to attract the right pool of suitably qualified candidates from which to make a selection. When completing the Vacancy request, Managers will include core information about the vacancy. Allowing the advert to be advertised
by the HR Recruitment team as soon as possible once the vacancy has been approved. Additionally they should ensure they attach:
A Job Description that has been job evaluated and approved
A Person Specification
Advert wording

The draft advert wording will need to be tailored to the level of applicant targeted. We recommend using NHS employer's available guidance to ensure compliance with regulation and specifically Equality legislation. It will need to contain a brief summary of main tasks and responsibilities from the job description and qualifications, minimum skill requirements from the person specification. All advertisements will automatically have added the Trust statement on early closing of adverts, equal opportunities, and our approach to flexible working. Managers can seek support from Human Resources in completing the vacancy request and discuss early on an advertising strategy if they are recruiting for a shortage skill area.

All vacancies will be advertised using NHS Jobs which can be accessed worldwide and is cost-free. If the advert proves unsuccessful, then the manager should contact Human Resources to discuss extending the advertisement and or looking at alternative methods.
The additional cost of recruiting to the vacancy must be considered at this stage and alternative methods used for which additional cost is incurred must be borne by the Department.
All vacancies will be advertised except in the following circumstances:
Where staff are identified as ‘at risk' and a suitable vacancy arises for redeployment.
Where staff are on the redeployment register due to health reasons and a suitable vacancy arises for redeployment.

*Where a temporary/ short term secondment opportunity is identified which meets the needs of the Trust and the personal development needs of an individual employee an expression of interest may be considered in consultation with the Recruitment service to ensure applicants of suitable qualification, grade and potential ability are able to apply internally.
Recruiting to vacancies using agencies for permanent or fixed term introduction

Where certain roles may fall to a critical shortage occupation list or are particularly niche in terms of their skill set the hiring manager may be authorised to recruit via an agency framework solution to widen the pool of candidate applicants.

This route of recruitment has to follow the afore mentioned recruitment process and thereafter should the post remain vacant a business case would need to be submitted to an executive with financial approval and modelling for the posts going forward so that the recruitment team can engage with a proactive campaign of recruitment.

Once the finance and business case approvals have been received the Recruitment business partner will approach agencies on our established preferred supplier list as engaged by framework award in order to gain suitable CVs and candidates for the hiring manager to review. The recruitment team would then arrange interviews subject to approvals from our procurement business partners and a confirmation from managers on shortlisted CVs.
It would be in direct circumvention of recruitment processes, NHS employer recruitment standards, Framework guidance, procurement rules and financial authority standing regulations for:
Managers to engage directly in permanent or fixed term recruitment activity without executive team business case approval, finance approval and recruitment team approval
Managers to approach off framework agencies for supply
Managers to approach suppliers directly to sign terms of business

In particular instances where the framework suppliers are unable to meet with the specific requirements of the role and we need to extend the reach of recruitment, the hiring manager may seek to undertake a paid for advertising campaign or alternatively we may need to approach off framework providers for potential supply. The recruitment business partner would need to raise the request to the appropriate procurement business partner to ensure that the agency is appropriately engaged and suitable sign off of the waiver documentation, finance paperwork and terms of business has been completed. Hiring managers are unable to engage directly with agencies for supply and or to sign terms of business with off framework suppliers' appendix 7 shows the flow chart for engaging agency supply.
Selection
Shortlisting

When the vacancy has closed, Human Resources will notify the Line Manager (or Panel) via the TRAC system and the Manager will be given access to see all the applicants who have applied for the vacancy. The recruiting manager will review the application forms and select those applicants they wish to shortlist for interview. Where there are ‘paper' applicants who have not been able to apply online, HR Recruitment team will provide a hard copy to the Line Manager to consider as part of the short listing.

The Line Manager will only have access to relevant information about candidates that enables them to short-list based upon the applicant's ability to do the job. Once the Manager has short-listed and alerted the Recruitment team. The team will invite short-listed applicants to interview and inform those applicants not short listed via TRAC.

Managers must use objective selection criteria and will therefore use the person specification and any additional relevant criteria e.g. well-reasoned and completed application form in their short listing decisions. This will have the added benefit that feedback may also be given to unsuccessful applicants.
Interviews

When applicants are invited to interview via TRAC, they may also be given details of the selection process e.g. interview followed by a presentation or test to be administered as part of the interview process.

Interview panels must always consist of at least 2 members of staff, one of whom should be the appointing manager. The composition of the panel should be designed to ensure the suitability of the applicants is properly and thoroughly assessed. There are some specific legislative requirements around interview panels for substantive medical appointments and Human Resources will ensure these requirements are met as part of arranging interviews for these posts. Human Resources will provide a digital interview pack for the Line Manager consisting of copies of the application forms, details of attendees, interview times and interview record sheets.

Interview Panel members should meet before the interview to prepare suitable questions. Interviewers should work to a structure of questions to assess the applicants against the criteria listed in the person specification and in the case of panel interviews; each interviewer should identify the questions that they will ask the applicants. Panel members should also consider any reasonable adjustments for any of the applicants who may have a disability.

The interview panel must not ask any questions relating to applicants personal circumstances. However if an applicant refers to their personal circumstances then the panel may respond but should be aware that the emphasis is on the candidates capability to perform the duties of the job.

The panel must also be aware the Equality Act 2010, makes asking questions about the health status of an individual applying for a post illegal until after they have been sent a conditional offer letter. Structured interviews ensure that the same areas are covered for all applicants and the interview is job related. The Panel should probe responses as necessary so that they are satisfied with the information given. Applicants' answers should be recorded and scored, see Appendix 1 so that an objective decision is made regarding the most suitable applicant. The opportunity should always be given to applicants to ask questions about the job for which they are applying, the terms and conditions which would apply and the organisation as a whole. As such, Line Managers should ensure they have information to hand where possible.

This will facilitate all parties having all the information they need from interview to either make a decision to offer or accept an offer of a post. Applicants should always be given an indication of the timescales involved in the recruitment process, how they will be notified of the outcome and in particular the need for any conditions to an offer of a post e.g. Occupational Health Report, Disclosure and Barring service check, references if these have not been obtained.

After the interview the Interview Panel will return all the paperwork to HR notifying the team of the successful candidate, and details of the offer. The hiring managers will provide feedback and notify the other applicants as to outcomes.
Interview expenses
It is only in exceptional cases that the Trust will provide interview expenses for either successful or unsuccessful interviewees.

Where it is exceptionally agreed to recompense applicants, this will be funded by the Line Manager's budget and will not exceed £150. Where an applicant is moving into the area, they may be eligible for assistance with the cost of relocation. Managers should check the eligibility criteria and approvals required in the Trust Relocation Expenses Policy prior to responding to an enquiry. For medical appointments, please contact the HR Recruitment team where there are specific entitlements dependent upon position and grade.
Employment offers

After interview, Line Managers will wish to make a verbal conditional offer of employment as quickly as possible and to avoid the chance of applicants accepting alternative offers from other employers.

A conditional offer is subject to satisfactory Mandatory NHS employment checks and the Recruiting Manager must take care to ensure the applicant doesn't resign their current role until HR Recruitment team on behalf of the Trust has received what it considers to be satisfactory employment checks. The Trust may subsequently withdraw an offer where satisfactory employment checks have not been received.

When an offer of employment is made to one candidate, the other candidates should also be informed they have been unsuccessful and that feedback on why they were unsuccessful is available from the Recruiting Manager. Where a conditional offer is made to one applicant the Manager may wish to hold another suitable applicant in ‘reserve'.
At the point in time when a conditional offer has been made Human Resources will create a new personal file and this will include copies and or originals of the following:
Completed Interview and appointment checklist
Application form
Copies of certificates/qualifications necessary for the post/professional registration details
Copies of identification / work permit / visas
References
Occupational Health Clearance Form
DBS certificate / Certificate of good standing / International police clearance
New starter form
Copy of contract.
Types of appointment
Permanent

These contracts are generally offered for both full time and part time positions, and usually set out the employee's salary and working hours. Other details included within a full-time contract include holiday entitlements, pension benefits, parental leave allowances, and details on Statutory Sick Pay (SSP). There is no set minimum number of hours that you must work on a full-time contract. However, the NHS recognises full-time work as 37.5 hours per week.
Fixed Term

Fixed-term contracts last for a specific amount of time, which has been set and agreed in advance. In some instances, fixed-term contracts may not include an exact timeframe, but will instead end when a specific task has been completed or fulfilled.

Fixed-term employees enjoy all of the same rights and benefits as with any other permanent contract, although factors such as holiday entitlement will depend on contract length. Fixed term contracts will also require a notice period of 1 month in order to terminate the contract. If the role itself becomes a viable permanent post then the person who has undertaken this role will be eligible to apply for the permanent post but the appropriate recruitment processes will need to be followed.
Secondment

A secondment is a temporary transfer to another role or business area away from your primary job. It allows you to get first-hand experience of another job role. Secondments at MSE are mostly internal however we do operate a wider NHS to NHS secondment arrangement but they can be more complex to arrange, as the contract details, including payment terms, need to be agreed in writing. The original NHS employer usually remains the official employer of the secondee, in an acknowledgement that they are ‘lending' their employee to the other Trust. These agreements extend for a finite period. i.e. 6 months
Bank

MSE has its own internal Bank which employs staff to work on casual basis. This allows the Trust to offer a worker hours of work which the worker is allowed to decline. The business will have no obligation to offer or provide the worker with a minimum amount of hours of work. The worker will not have the legal status of an employee. The Bank will issue a casual worker agreement to the bank joiner which will detail all the information they need to understand their entitlement to pay, holiday and benefits, and clearly details other key issues such as hours and place of work. The agreement will also set out the details for the worker if they elect to opt out of the working time directive 48 hour limit.
Permanent contracted role to ‘Pure Bank'

As a flexible employer, MSE does allow for substantive staff to discuss with their managers and gain agreement for a termination of their permanent contract and its terms to enable a move for their employment to be purely on a casual basis through the bank. The worker will need a termination form completed and a new recruitment process to ensure the correct adjustment to their contract. These candidates need to understand that they are not guaranteed work and nor the same position on a consistent basis through the bank. They also lose their substantive employment rights.
Retire and return

In particularly specialist or hard to fill roles, managers may discuss with retiring staff members the possibility for them to return to the role on a fixed term basis. I.e. whilst the workforce plan is being readjusted or they are trying to recruit to the post. At the point of submitting retirement paperwork and termination forms to the Workforce ESR team a new recruitment process will need to commence. This is due to the HMRC requirements for the individual to be terminated from employment for at least 24 hours to ensure the end of the previous NHS service that would affect their pension and benefits. The new recruitment episode and contract will ensure they are on a new fixed term assignment. As a retire returnee HMRC stipulates that you are only able to work  hours per work for the first month of employment and thereafter can revert to full time hours. * Managers need carefully consider the benefits of retire and return than the candidate joining the bank as a pure bank staff member instead.
Promotional appointments

Promotional appointments need to follow correct, and equitable NHS employment guidance and processes. These processes should be advertised on the TRAC system and be advertised externally to ensure best practise and the best possible applicants for the post. In certain circumstances if there are a number of internal candidates that may be suited to the post these can be advertised internally via TRAC. In these processes candidate will need to be interviewed by a panel and appointed as per regular recruitment processes and standards. Thereafter a Contractual change form will need to be completed by the hiring manager to ensure the candidate is moved onto their new role on ESR and Health Roster system.

Expressions of interest may be used in exceptional circumstances if individuals have been acting up into that post and they would like to confirm them into this post. However this needs to be discussed with the Recruitment managers to ensure knowledge and equity in the process. All appropriate recruitment processes need to be followed including sending the interview paperwork to the recruitment team so that the team can complete the necessary checks.
Pre-employment checks for all employees
References

In summary and as part of the NHS Mandatory Employment Checks the Trust will require written References for all applicants covering the last three years of employment and/or training and from two separate employers. When an individual has been with the trust for 3 years or more, one reference from the line manager may be sufficient. In the case of someone who has never been employed, a reference can be supplied from the candidate's school or college or from a responsible person in the community. Further details of disclosure of references are to be found in the Trust References Policy which all managers should make themselves familiar with.
Right to work in the UK/ identification check

The NHS Mandatory Employment Checks and the Asylum and Immigration Act 1996 require the Trust to ensure that all new employees are eligible to be employed in the UK by seeing an original copy of relevant documentation listed in Appendix  Failure to do this prior to employing an individual is a criminal offence. All short listed applicants are requested to bring their identification documents. Only original documents are acceptable.

Human Resources will not issue an employment contract until the necessary proof of the employees' eligibility to work in the UK have been reviewed and confirmed as valid. If a Manager has interviewed an applicant who is not a British Citizen or otherwise has the right of abode here, we would need to apply for a work permit if we wished to appoint them. The Home Office will only issue a work permit if we can prove it has not been possible to recruit from the UK or that the position if for a critical shortage occupation specialty. Please contact the Human Resources department if you wish to interview/select an applicant who will need a work permit or visa
Once a work permit is issued, Human Resources will monitor the expiry dates of the work permits via ESR to ensure legal compliance is maintained.
Disclosure and barring service (DBS) checks

In accordance with the Trust DBS policy, all new employees to certain posts and employees moving to those posts within the Trust will be required to undergo a DBS check. Human Resources will accept DBS checks that have been carried out within the last 12 months, whilst we carry out a new check. We will also accept DBS certificates accompanied by an online confirmation of sign up to the DBS update service.

Although having a criminal record is not a bar to employment, the Trust will not employ individuals who have been formally disqualified from working with children or vulnerable adults. In all other cases, the Trust will consider each case on its
individual merits using criteria set out in the Risk Assessment Procedure. Human Resources will be responsible for ensuring the DBS checks are carried out.
Professional registration

Where an applicant has applied for a post which requires registration with a professional body, then the status of their registration will be checked directly with the relevant professional body. For health professionals, verifying professional registration negates the need to verify qualifications separately.

The Recruitment team will check successful applicants to ensure they are appropriately registered prior to them commencing work. By using the General Medical Council website, HPAN, the Nursing and Midwifery Council website, the Health and Care Professions Council website, The Society of Clinical Perfusion Scientists or the Royal Pharmaceutical Society Great Britain website; managers can check the registration status of applicants and identify if there are any conditions of practice.

If there are conditions of practice attached to the applicant's professional registration they will need to provide a statement of relevant information surrounding the conditions so that a risk assessment can be undertaken by the hiring manager, lead for the service and the lead for the profession.

For non-health professionals, key qualifications and membership of professional bodies should be verified separately This is should be confirmed by taking copies of certificates at interview and checking with the appropriate professional body prior to the successful applicant commencing work.
Alert notices

The Trust screens potential employees for alert notices. Prior to issuing contracts of employment, all new and existing employees are checked by Human Resources staff against the alerts that are in place to ensure the employee is not the subject of a current alert. In addition, as all alerts should also be referred to the appropriate regulatory professional body, when registration checks are made by managers prior to interview and again prior to employment, this two pronged approach ensures that those applicants who are interviewed and selected are appropriately qualified and not the subject of an NHS alert.
Occupational health clearance

The Equality Act  makes asking questions about the health status of an individual applying for a post illegal until after they have been made a conditional offer letter. Once the conditional offer has been made HR Recruitment team will follow the appropriate Occupational health clearance process depending on job role the applicant is being recruited to.

If a Health Questionnaire is sent via online link to the applicant, the candidates responses are confidential between OH & the prospective employee and under no circumstances can be accessed by the manager or member of their team.
Applicants are not permitted to commence work for the Trust without having been cleared as fit to work by Occupational Health.

Human Resources will contact the manager and if necessary will ask the manager to clarify with the OH department if there are any restrictions on their fit certificate. Following clearance the HR Recruitment team will let the applicant know when all the pre-employment checks are complete and agree a start date for the contract of employment. The responsibility for ensuring ongoing occupational health fitness clearance falls to the line manager and the candidate to maintain.
Commencing employment
Salary

The Trust's policy is that the starting salary for a new employee would normally be on the bottom of the Band, as per Agenda for Change. Bank Experience is not recognised in AFC automatically reverting to the starting point of the scale. However an applicant or new joiner may start on a higher point than the bottom of the band if relevant documentation has been presented to approve this. For example a pre hire Inter Authority Transfer (IAT); the new employee producing their last 3 payslips and the manager completing a starting salary variation form Appendix 6 to send to the Vacancy Control Panel for approval.
Joining process Producing a Smartcard

For all new employees HR Registered Authority (RA) team will take responsibility of producing a Smartcard. The card will be produced on the employees first day, an appointment will be arranged by HR with the candidate prior to them starting. Please note that HR RA team only deal with the new starters after this point all issues regarding Smartcards please contact the RA Helpdesk.
General joining requirements
The Manager must ensure all practical arrangements are considered and plans made to welcome the new employee including:
If accommodation has been offered ensure the new employee is advised of the booking arrangement in advance.
Where uniforms are required, details for the fitting and collection are provided.
Arrangements are in place for the new employee to attend the Trust Induction (i.e. dates are confirmed with HR Recruitment team and candidate).
To be met on the first day in the department/ward and that a departmental induction has been arranged.
Completion with the new employee of the new starter form and returned relevant copies to Human Resources and Payroll to ensure the new employee is paid appropriately.

To once again confirm that the employees professional registration is up to date and note when it should be renewed for ongoing monitoring Ensure the pre- employment checks were all satisfactorily completed.
The Trust considers these issues a very important part of the recruitment process and it is the manager's responsibility to ensure a positive first impression is made for the new employee.
Ensuring safe employees on an ongoing basis

It is a contractual requirement of all employees to alert their Manager of any criminal conviction as an employee, including any driving offences. Any convictions gained by existing employees are to be referred to Human Resources to ensure the employment relationship is still appropriate.
Ongoing registration and fitness to practice is discussed further in the Policy for Organisational Checks on Professional Registration.

Employees who do not have permanent entitlement to reside and work in the UK are monitored in Human Resources. Where an entitlement is due to expire, Human Resources will contact the Manager of the employee to ensure the Trust remains compliant with Immigration law.
Changes to employment

Changes to employee circumstance may affect their personal details on ESR. If there are changes to address or bank account details or address the workforce team need to be notified by the change of personal details form.
Human Resources will be responsible for gathering performance indicators and using them to evaluate the effectiveness of this policy.
Training requirements
Hiring Manager Recruitment and Selection Training:
At the commencement of their employment, a hiring manager will need to undertake a suite of leadership and development training modules of which recruitment and selection training

Managers or team members who may administer parts of the recruitment process through our applicant management system will need TRAC system training. TRAC training can be provided in person or via video call with HR, there are also videos available on the Trust intranet.
Monitoring and audit

The Monitoring of the recruitment process is audited randomly and the processes and requirements of both Human Resources and the relevant Manager are checked for completeness by a member of HR, internal regulatory mechanisms and external regulatory bodies i.e. UKVI
Every new starters file is checked before it is downloaded and securely saved. The recruitment time of every vacancy is monitored and analysed monthly.
Human Resources will be responsible for gathering performance indicators and using them to evaluate the effectiveness of this policy.
Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the HR Policy Working Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the recruiting managers of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.

Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust
Guidance on starting salaries payable for staff on contracts linked to Agenda for Change (A4C) Terms and conditions of Service
1.0 Introduction and context
The introduction of Agenda for Change (AfC) in  was a significant achievement; bringing together several pay arrangements into one overall structure underpinned by job evaluation.

An agreement was reached in England that changes were required in order to modernise AfC in a number of areas. The agreement reached in 2013 was recognised as the start of a wider conversation on a refresh of AfC. The  year pay deal incorporating further changes covers the period from 1 April 2018 to  March 2021.

A new rate of £17,460 (equivalent to 8.92 per hour which exceeds the living wage) was introduced in April 2018 as the minimum basic pay rate in the NHS to ensure that the NHS in England retains a competitive market advantage in the jobs market for staff employed at this level. Band 1 was uprated to this minimum pay rate and the band was closed to new entrants from 1 December 2018.
A framework was agreed to support and encourage upskilling band 1 roles to band 2 roles. This exercise is to be completed byMarch

The starting salaries across all pay bands will have cumulative changes as illustrated in the table at section 2.1 below. Points which overlap with a lower pay band will be removed from the bottom of the current pay band, with one point already removed in 2018/2019, and further points being removed in 2019/2020.

It is important to note a new provision detailing pay for apprentices will be negotiated and will be added to the updated NHS terms and conditions of service handbook. This will help employers make maximum use of the apprenticeship levy, to develop both new and the existing workforce and to increase capacity.
The top pay points for bands 2 – 8c increase as follows:
1.7 per cent in 2019/2020
1.67 per cent in 2020/2021
The level of the top pay points in bands 8D and 9 will be capped at the level of the increase in value at the top of band 8c (i.e. the same monetary value for the top of Bands 8C, 8D and 9).
Starting salaries
Cumulative changes from 2017/2018
Pay steps effective from 1 April 2019
Bands 2, 3, 4, 8a, 8b, 8c, 8d and 9 will have 2 pay steps, a starting point and a top point.
Bands 5, 6 and 7 will have 3 pay steps, a starting point, an intermediate point and a top point.
Staff joining the Trust without previous NHS service / experience
It is expected that staff new to the NHS will be appointed to the bottom of the relevant band.

Although there is an element of discretion that the employer may apply, this is restricted in line with 2.2 above. The pay progression is tied to the number of years of experience and the skills level and appraisals.

If appointing above the entry level, credit may be given for previous years of equivalent or higher responsibility. Salary in the previous role cannot be used as evidence that the previous role had comparable levels of skills, experience and responsibility.
Appropriate evidence to confirm comparable responsibilities include but are not limited to, references, continuous professional development and job descriptions.
Other factors to be considered when deciding whether to award above entry level salary:
Impact or potential impact on other members of the team, particularly those on the same pay band.
The difficulty of filling the role
Continuous professional development (CPD)
The affordability of the increase.
Precedence setting

Pay variation will be restricted and will not be automatically applicable. Managers do not have discretion to agree starting salaries at interview or via the offer of employment. Should a manager believe their new candidate for employment should be in receipt of a variation, they must complete and sign the form at Appendix  Please note that there is no guarantee that the application will be approved by the vacancy control group.
Staff joining MSE from another NHS organisation

Staff joining MSE and who take up a role at the same banding as the previous role will remain on the same pay step as they were paid by the previous NHS employer and will retain their pay progression step date until March 2021.

Staff joining MSE and taking up a role with a higher banding on or after 1 April 2019, will be paid in line Annex  of the NHS terms and conditions and their pay progression step date will be on the anniversary of their starting date.
Additional payments paid by the previous organisation, for example, high cost areas supplement (HCAS) are not taken into consideration when identifying starting salary to be paid by MSE.
MSE will pay staff joining the Trust the High Cost Area Allowance ‘fringe' in addition to their basic salary at the rate specified in the AfC TCS handbook.
Staff joining MSE from another NHS organisation following a break in service.
A break in service is regarded as a period of three months or more between the termination and resumption of employment in the NHS.
Staff appointed after a break in service (see above) will normally be at the entry level of the band. Pay progression step date will be anniversary of appointment.
Additional payments paid by the previous organisation (for example HCAS) are not taken into consideration when identifying starting salary to be paid by MSE.
MSE will pay staff joining the Trust the High Cost Area Allowance ‘fringe' in addition to their basic salary at the rate specified in the AfC TCS handbook.
2.4.1 When deciding to award a higher starting salary consideration must be given to the following;
An employee cannot enter at a point higher than they would have been prior to the break (unless they have comparable non-NHS service during the break which may need to be considered)
The relevance of the previous experience.
Impact or potential impact on other members of the team, particularly those on the same pay band.
Evidence of their appraisals and continuous professional development (CPD).
The difficulty of filling the role
The affordability of the increase.
Precedent setting

NOTE  Managers are  advised  not to  discuss  starting  salaries  with  candidates  and  to consult with their Human Resources Business Partner should a variation of starting salary be sought. All posts will be advertised at the entry level salary.
